Why can't BFD be used for the same functionality - testing of reacheability and connectivity ? BFD SAI API is already defined

> Why can't BFD be used for the same functionality - testing of reacheability and connectivity ? BFD SAI API is already defined

This requirement pertains to the SONIC Dualtor scenario, which employs an ICMP-based link prober. For further insights, refer to the documentation at: https://github.com/sonic-net/SONiC/blob/master/doc/dualtor/active_active_hld.md. In this scenario, both links present the same IP and MAC address to the server, a configuration that is incompatible with BFD  due to its requirement for unique IP addresses for a single hop / direct links.

I have some basic questions on the feature itself and then suggestions for spec.

Questions:
1. Is this between two peering links or across hops?
2. How do you differentiate between ICMP echo response being dropped because of other network conditions instead of link down?
3. ICMP packets are typically handled in slow path. For this to work the end points MUST have HW offload capability. Is this understanding correct?

> I have some basic questions on the feature itself and then suggestions for spec.
> 
> Questions:
> 
>     1. Is this between two peering links or across hops?
> 
>     2. How do you differentiate between ICMP echo response being dropped because of other network conditions instead of link down?
> 
>     3. ICMP packets are typically handled in slow path. For this to work the end points MUST have HW offload capability. Is this understanding correct?

1.  It can be either.
2. There's no distinction. In this context, "link down" encompasses both scenarios.
3. Yes, that's correct. However, it should function with other combinations (such as HW offload to SW module, or SW module to SW module implementations) as long as the configured intervals accommodate the expected transaction rate or slowness.

> This specification suggests:
> 
> * The idea of an ICMP echo object or session that can be transferred to HW/ASIC or other modules for faster link detection.
> * The introduction of SAI APIs to outline ICMP echo session properties.
> * The introduction of a switch-level notification API to monitor changes in ICMP echo session states.

Hi Chikke,

At 100ms granularity, I don't see a reason for HW offload.
If we want to go faster (which we should), as Eddy suggested, BFD is a much better alternative. 

Your BFD statement above is incorrect.

RFC5880 states:
Since multiple BFD sessions may be running between two systems, there needs to be a mechanism for demultiplexing received BFD packets to the proper session.
Each system MUST choose an opaque discriminator value that identifies each session, and which MUST be unique among all BFD sessions on the system. The local discriminator is sent in the My Discriminator field in the BFD Control packet, and is echoed back in the Your Discriminator field of packets sent from the remote end.   

Specifically to single hop BFD (which is the case here) RFC5881 states:
On a point-to-point link, the source address of a BFD Control packetvMUST NOT be used to identify the session.  This means that thevinitial BFD packet MUST be accepted with any source address, and thatvsubsequent BFD packets MUST be demultiplexed solely by the YourvDiscriminator field (as is always the case)

> > This specification suggests:
> > 
> > * The idea of an ICMP echo object or session that can be transferred to HW/ASIC or other modules for faster link detection.
> > * The introduction of SAI APIs to outline ICMP echo session properties.
> > * The introduction of a switch-level notification API to monitor changes in ICMP echo session states.
> 
> Hi Chikke,
> 
> At 100ms granularity, I don't see a reason for HW offload. If we want to go faster (which we should), as Eddy suggested, BFD is a much better alternative.
> 
> Your BFD statement above is incorrect.
> 
> RFC5880 states: Since multiple BFD sessions may be running between two systems, there needs to be a mechanism for demultiplexing received BFD packets to the proper session. Each system MUST choose an opaque discriminator value that identifies each session, and which MUST be unique among all BFD sessions on the system. The local discriminator is sent in the My Discriminator field in the BFD Control packet, and is echoed back in the Your Discriminator field of packets sent from the remote end.
> 
> Specifically to single hop BFD (which is the case here) RFC5881 states: On a point-to-point link, the source address of a BFD Control packetvMUST NOT be used to identify the session. This means that thevinitial BFD packet MUST be accepted with any source address, and thatvsubsequent BFD packets MUST be demultiplexed solely by the YourvDiscriminator field (as is always the case)

Hi Jeff, 
Yes, the requirement is to go much faster than 100ms. Original requirement is from SONIC dualtor use case. 

You are right about IP addresses. Thank you correcting me. 

I didn’t explain clearly. I meant to mention the following of RFC 5881:
......
Initialization and Demultiplexing

   In this application, there will be only a single BFD session between
   two systems over a given interface (logical or physical) for a
   particular protocol.  The BFD session must be bound to this
   interface.  As such, both sides of a session MUST take the "Active"
   role (sending initial BFD Control packets with a zero value of Your
   Discriminator), and any BFD packet from the remote machine with a
   zero value of Your Discriminator MUST be associated with the session
   bound to the remote system, interface, and protocol.
......
For example, in case of SONIC dualtor active-active use case, there will be two sessions between ToR and server over a single physical link. The server basically duplicates ICMP heartbeat to both ToRs, that means each tor will receive TWO icmp replies. One originates from local, the other is from peer.  That way, a ToR can monitor the health status of  server link and  its peer ToR as well. 

Couple of other reasons that I think this will help: 
-	Not all NF/devices support BFD as compared to ICMP.  
-	BFD has overhead of session establishment and negotiation. 

Please correct me If I’m wrong or  have missed something. 

Thanks
Chikke

> > > This specification suggests:
> > > 
> > > * The idea of an ICMP echo object or session that can be transferred to HW/ASIC or other modules for faster link detection.
> > > * The introduction of SAI APIs to outline ICMP echo session properties.
> > > * The introduction of a switch-level notification API to monitor changes in ICMP echo session states.
> > 
> > 
> > Hi Chikke,
> > At 100ms granularity, I don't see a reason for HW offload. If we want to go faster (which we should), as Eddy suggested, BFD is a much better alternative.
> > Your BFD statement above is incorrect.
> > RFC5880 states: Since multiple BFD sessions may be running between two systems, there needs to be a mechanism for demultiplexing received BFD packets to the proper session. Each system MUST choose an opaque discriminator value that identifies each session, and which MUST be unique among all BFD sessions on the system. The local discriminator is sent in the My Discriminator field in the BFD Control packet, and is echoed back in the Your Discriminator field of packets sent from the remote end.
> > Specifically to single hop BFD (which is the case here) RFC5881 states: On a point-to-point link, the source address of a BFD Control packetvMUST NOT be used to identify the session. This means that thevinitial BFD packet MUST be accepted with any source address, and thatvsubsequent BFD packets MUST be demultiplexed solely by the YourvDiscriminator field (as is always the case)
> 
> Hi Jeff, Yes, the requirement is to go much faster than 100ms. Original requirement is from SONIC dualtor use case.
> 
> You are right about IP addresses. Thank you correcting me.
> 
> I didn’t explain clearly. I meant to mention the following of RFC 5881: ...... Initialization and Demultiplexing
> 
> In this application, there will be only a single BFD session between two systems over a given interface (logical or physical) for a particular protocol. The BFD session must be bound to this interface. As such, both sides of a session MUST take the "Active" role (sending initial BFD Control packets with a zero value of Your Discriminator), and any BFD packet from the remote machine with a zero value of Your Discriminator MUST be associated with the session bound to the remote system, interface, and protocol. ...... For example, in case of SONIC dualtor active-active use case, there will be two sessions between ToR and server over a single physical link. The server basically duplicates ICMP heartbeat to both ToRs, that means each tor will receive TWO icmp replies. One originates from local, the other is from peer. That way, a ToR can monitor the health status of server link and its peer ToR as well.
> 
> Couple of other reasons that I think this will help:
> 
> * Not all NF/devices support BFD as compared to ICMP.
> * BFD has overhead of session establishment and negotiation.
> 
> Please correct me If I’m wrong or have missed something.
> 
> Thanks Chikke

Hi Chikke,

Even if you plan to change the default interval for ICMP probing in Dual-TOR from 100ms to something smaller, still the link is considered unhealthy after 3 retries. So, even if you configurre 100ms --> 50ms, still 50x3=150ms is big enough time that hardly justifies the HW offloading

> > > > This specification suggests:
> > > > 
> > > > * The idea of an ICMP echo object or session that can be transferred to HW/ASIC or other modules for faster link detection.
> > > > * The introduction of SAI APIs to outline ICMP echo session properties.
> > > > * The introduction of a switch-level notification API to monitor changes in ICMP echo session states.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Hi Chikke,
> > > At 100ms granularity, I don't see a reason for HW offload. If we want to go faster (which we should), as Eddy suggested, BFD is a much better alternative.
> > > Your BFD statement above is incorrect.
> > > RFC5880 states: Since multiple BFD sessions may be running between two systems, there needs to be a mechanism for demultiplexing received BFD packets to the proper session. Each system MUST choose an opaque discriminator value that identifies each session, and which MUST be unique among all BFD sessions on the system. The local discriminator is sent in the My Discriminator field in the BFD Control packet, and is echoed back in the Your Discriminator field of packets sent from the remote end.
> > > Specifically to single hop BFD (which is the case here) RFC5881 states: On a point-to-point link, the source address of a BFD Control packetvMUST NOT be used to identify the session. This means that thevinitial BFD packet MUST be accepted with any source address, and thatvsubsequent BFD packets MUST be demultiplexed solely by the YourvDiscriminator field (as is always the case)
> > 
> > 
> > Hi Jeff, Yes, the requirement is to go much faster than 100ms. Original requirement is from SONIC dualtor use case.
> > You are right about IP addresses. Thank you correcting me.
> > I didn’t explain clearly. I meant to mention the following of RFC 5881: ...... Initialization and Demultiplexing
> > In this application, there will be only a single BFD session between two systems over a given interface (logical or physical) for a particular protocol. The BFD session must be bound to this interface. As such, both sides of a session MUST take the "Active" role (sending initial BFD Control packets with a zero value of Your Discriminator), and any BFD packet from the remote machine with a zero value of Your Discriminator MUST be associated with the session bound to the remote system, interface, and protocol. ...... For example, in case of SONIC dualtor active-active use case, there will be two sessions between ToR and server over a single physical link. The server basically duplicates ICMP heartbeat to both ToRs, that means each tor will receive TWO icmp replies. One originates from local, the other is from peer. That way, a ToR can monitor the health status of server link and its peer ToR as well.
> > Couple of other reasons that I think this will help:
> > 
> > * Not all NF/devices support BFD as compared to ICMP.
> > * BFD has overhead of session establishment and negotiation.
> > 
> > Please correct me If I’m wrong or have missed something.
> > Thanks Chikke
> 
> Hi Chikke,
> 
> Even if you plan to change the default interval for ICMP probing in Dual-TOR from 100ms to something smaller, still the link is considered unhealthy after 3 retries. So, even if you configurre 100ms --> 50ms, still 50x3=150ms is big enough time that hardly justifies the HW offloading

Hi Eddy, 
With the HW offload, packet are exchanges at micro sec rate. Detection can be performed in a few miliseconds. Also, this greatly helps if switchover from active to standby done in the HW directly.

Today in SAI pipeline for L3/routed packets, dst mac/src mac/vlan id are replaced in neighbor encap/egress rif block.  We discussed in SAI Meeting if these knobs should be in neighbor or rif object instead.  However, if disable L3 rewrite are only for certain IP flows and not for entire egress IP interface/neighbor, it'd still be better to stay at next hop object.

Proposal document.
[Uploading SAI_Cable_Diagnostics_Port_Attribute_v0.docx…]()

@jiahua-wang , @prafull-brcm , 
1. please change the doc to md format and incoporate this into the PR.
2. can you clarify the example, make the create_port optional. as my understand, we can also set the port cable type to CAT6.
3. as my understanding, the diagnostic process happened during the query for the attributes. when you query status, it runs on diagnose once, when you try to get length, it will run another time.

> @jiahua-wang , @prafull-brcm ,
> 
> 1. please change the doc to md format and incoporate this into the PR.
> 2. can you clarify the example, make the create_port optional. as my understand, we can also set the port cable type to CAT6.
> 3. as my understanding, the diagnostic process happened during the query for the attributes. when you query status, it runs on diagnose once, when you try to get length, it will run another time.
@lguohan 
1. I incorporated the the document in the PR in md format
2. I mentioned in example that using set property cable type can be set.
3. Yes it is correct, Run diagnostics command runs for both cable pair status and cable length in this case  but it is implementation specific. The cable length information can be cached once Cable Pair status is requested, it can be read at the same time and can be stored to read latter.

@lguohan 
Updated the documentation in proper md format.
